steps.text:
This site is home to the original variant of chess called ”Token.” 
  
 Here you can learn the game, analyze custom positions, or play with a friend.
This tutorial explains the concept of the game, and contains instructions for using available features.

standard-rules.title: Chess
standard-rules.quote: “The game of chess is a lake in which a mosquito can bathe and an elephant can drown.” – Indian Proverb

steps.text:
Chess is a board game that has been played for roughly half a millenium. 
 To learn the basics of the game, [lichess.org](https://lichess.org/learn) is a great comprehensive source.

In understanding the concept of chess *variants*, it helps to know that chess itself is a European *variation* of a type of board game that has existed for around 1,000 years longer than modern chess. The original game, [Chaturanga](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chaturanga), spread to other regions and evolved into [Xiangqi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi), [Shogi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shogi), and many other variations. These variations have different pieces and rules, but share the concept of a coordinate system and a set of movable figures, one of which is deemed important.

fairy-chess.title: Fairy Chess
fairy-chess.quote: “We do these things for ourselves alone.” – Thomas Rayner Dawson, fairy chess composer

steps.text: “Fairy Chess“ is a general term for a chess variant that includes nonstandard piece types, or “fairy pieces.“

Below is a [variant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knighted_chess) imagined by third world chess champion José Raúl Capablanca. 
 Note the unorthodox 10x8 board and the addition of two fairy pieces.

It was popular in some historical chess communities to include fairy pieces in chess compositions. 
 The puzzle below was composed in 1911 by [Thomas Rayner Dawson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Rayner_Dawson), a prolific fairy chess composer. 
 It involves a fairy piece which combines the movement of a rook and a knight.
steps.note: White to move, mate in two.

token-chess.title: Token
token-chess.quote: “The ~~pawn~~ token is the soul of chess.” – François-André Danican Philidor

steps.text:
Token adds a unique collection of fairy pieces and a draft system to the standard game of chess. 
 Each piece has a set value measured in ”tokens,” and players draft their starting piece setup with a budget of 39 tokens.
steps.note: An example Token Chess starting position. There is no correct move here, the possibilities are endless!

steps.text: More information on drafting is detailed in the ”setup” section of this tutorial.

Champion.title: Champion
Champion.quote: “Suffer now and live the rest of your life as a champion.” – Muhammad Ali

steps.text:
The Champion combines the movement of the Rook and Knight pieces. It is a classic addition in chess variants. 
 In Token, it takes the name given by Italian priest [Pietro Carerra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pietro_Carrera), who first introduced the *Campione* to western chess in the 17th century.
steps.note: Capture the pawn, then the knight.

steps.text: You can castle with the Champion, just as you would a rook!
steps.note: Castle with the Champion.

Princess.title: Princess
Princess.quote: “Your princess is quite a winning creature. Her appeal is undeniable.” – Count Rugen

steps.text:
The Princess combines the movement of the Bishop and Knight. 
 The combination of short and long range strength makes her exceedingly tricky to play against.
steps.note: White to move, mate in one.

steps.text: As seen in the above example, one advantage of the Princess is her ability to checkmate a cornered king without additional help. Below is a slightly more complex illustration of this idea.
steps.note: Find the checkmate in two. (Difficulty: Medium)

Amazon.title: Amazon
Amazon.quote: “I will not be triumphed over.” – Cleopatra VII

steps.text:
Behold! The all-powerful Queen+Knight hybrid, popularly called the [Amazon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amazons) in reference to greek mythology. 
 Impressively, she can checkmate a king on the edge of the board without help from another piece.
steps.note: White to move, mate in one. (Bonus: find both solutions!)

steps.text:
It is nearly impossible to survive more than a few moves against an Amazon in endgame play. 
 In a more advanced example below, the Amazon easily overcomes a Champion with a beautiful *zugzwang*.
steps.note: Defeat the Champion. (Difficulty: Hard)

Mann.title: Mann
Mann.quote: “Every man dies. Not every man really lives.” – William Wallace

steps.text:
A Mann is equivalent to the King, but as he was not born into royalty the game does not hinge on its well-being. 
 Most valuable in endgames, he can deliver checkmate to a king unlike his minor piece counterparts.
steps.note: White to move, mate in two.

steps.text: A Mann is a great protector of the King. The below example demonstrates his ability to hold a draw against a Queen.
steps.note: Use the Mann to block the checks.

Painter.title: Painter
Painter.quote: “I dream my paintings, and then I paint my dreams.” – Vincent van Gogh

steps.text:
While similar to a pawn, a Painter has no violence in their heart. They are a dreamer, but not a fighter. 
 Rather than capture, the Painter *paints* pieces the opposite color.
steps.note: Push the Painter, then paint the rook.

steps.text:
Even when [promoting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Promotion_(chess)), the Painter refuses to pick up a sword. 
 Instead, it becomes the *Royal Painter*, which moves like a Queen but *paints* instead of capturing.
steps.note: White to move and win.

steps.text:
The Snare is a piece that does not capture, but restricts the movement of opposing pieces directly next to or in front of it. 
 In the diagram below, the rooks *cannot* move, but the knights can.

The Snare moves forward one square, straight or diagonally. 
 This example demonstrates the ability of a snare to assist in capturing a valuable target, such as a queen.
steps.note: Ensnare the opposing queen, then attack it with a pawn.

steps.text:
Note that since the Snare cannot capture, it cannot give check. 
 However, a Snare can trap a king, often leading to an easy checkmate!
steps.note: White to move, mate in two.

steps.text:
Like the Painter, the Snare does *not* promote like a pawn. 
 It promotes to a *Rolling Snare,* which can move 2 squares in any direction. Unlike the Snare, it also traps pieces directly *behind* it.
steps.note: White to move, mate in three.

Wizard.title: Wizard
Wizard.quote: “A wizard is never late. Nor is he early. He arrives precisely when he means to.” – Gandalf

steps.text: The Wizard moves up to two squares like a queen. Like a knight, the Wizard can jump over any pieces in the way.
steps.note: Jump over the pawn, then capture the queen.

steps.text: The Wizard has the ability to swap places with a friendly piece within its movement range. This ability disregards pins, contrary to standard chess rules which disallow moving “through“ check.
steps.note: Escape the pin.

steps.text: The Wizard may be used to escape the King from dangerous places, including positions which would otherwise be checkmate!
steps.note: Escape the checkmate attempt.

Archer.title: Archer
Archer.quote: “Swift as the wind, silent as the forest.” – Sun Tzu

steps.text: The Archer is a slow piece, moving one square diagonally at a time. This makes it a color-bound piece, like the Bishop.
steps.note: Capture the pawns.

steps.text: The Archer has the unique ability to capture without moving, given that the captured piece is 2 to 3 diagonal squares away.
steps.note: Capture the pieces in the following order: Knight, Rook, Pawn

token-values.title: Tokens
token-values.quote: “The ~~pawn~~ token is the soul of chess.” – François-André Danican Philidor

steps.text:
The token is a unit of measurement for a single piece's value in a game. 
 The value is used to determine what is allowed in a starting setup or **draft**, described in the next section. 
 It is equivalent to evaluating pieces in units of pawns.  
 For example, standard chess theory holds that a Knight is worth 3 pawns, a Rook 5 pawns, a Queen 9 pawns, *etc.*

Note that this game is a work in progess, so a piece's evaluation may change in future updates as a measure of balance. As of January 2026, the value in tokens for each piece is as follows: 
 
 Pawn: 1 
 Knight: 3 
 Bishop: 3 
 Rook : 5 
 Queen: 9 
 Champion: 8 
 Princess: 8 
 Amazon: 13 
 Mann: 3 
 Painter: 2 
 Snare: 2 
 Wizard: 4 
 Archer: 7
To create a draft, sign up and log in to a Token Chess account. Then click on the 'My Drafts' button in the top right corner. Here you can create and save up to 5 drafts for playing games.

In order to play a multiplayer game, one of your drafts must be set as 'Active' using the button on the drafts page. 
 This will be the draft used for playing games and may be changed between games.

As a balance measure, there are special restrictions on the quantity of each piece type in a draft. For example, one can only place a single Archer, or up to 2 Queens, or 4 Mannen, etc. This is designed to promote diversity in piece choice to keep things fun. In the above example, white's horde of Archers is nearly impossible to face.
